verses.text: On the first day of the week, at early dawn, they went to the tomb, bringing the spices they had prepared.
verses.comment: The women come to the tomb early, showing their devotion. The 'first day of the week' signals the new creation begun in Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: They found the stone rolled away from the tomb.
verses.comment: The rolling away of the stone demonstrates divine intervention, enabling witness to the empty tomb.

verses.text: But when they entered, they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
verses.comment: 'Lord Jesus' is a clear statement of His divinity. The empty tomb is an empirical sign pointing towards the resurrection.

verses.text: While they were perplexed about this, suddenly two men in dazzling clothes stood beside them.
verses.comment: The two men are understood as angels, common witnesses to God's powerful acts as in the Old Testament theophanies.

verses.text: As they were frightened and bowed their faces to the ground, the men said to them, 'Why do you seek the living among the dead?'
verses.comment: 'Bowing faces to the ground' signifies reverence for the divine. The question reminds us that Christ is alive, not bound by death.

verses.text: 'He is not here, but is risen! Remember how He spoke to you while He was still in Galilee,
verses.comment: 'He is risen' is the heart of the resurrection proclamation. Jesus' predictions are recalled, fulfilling His own prophecy.

verses.text: 'saying that the Son of Man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and on the third day rise.'
verses.comment: 'Son of Man' draws on Daniel 7:13-14, emphasizing Jesus' heavenly authority and messianic character. The necessity of passion and resurrection was always central to His mission.

verses.text: Then they remembered His words.
verses.comment: The disciples' understanding only comes by remembering and interpreting Jesus' teachings in light of God's plan.

verses.text: Returning from the tomb, they reported all these things to the Eleven and to all the rest.
verses.comment: The women are the first witnesses to the resurrection, a profound sign that God's revelation overturns cultural expectations.

verses.text: Now it was Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and the other women with them who told these things to the apostles.
verses.comment: By naming the women, Luke highlights the credibility and continuity of the apostolic witness.

verses.text: But these words appeared to them as nonsense, and they did not believe them.
verses.comment: The apostles initially doubt the resurrection report, revealing their need for grace to believe—a theme throughout scripture.

verses.text: But Peter rose and ran to the tomb. Stooping in, he saw the linen cloths by themselves, and he went away, marveling at what had happened.
verses.comment: Peter, the chief apostle, is given special mention, already hinting at his leading role in the community and in proclaiming the resurrection.

verses.text: Now, that same day, two of them were going to a village named Emmaus, about seven miles from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The journey from Jerusalem to Emmaus sets the scene for a profound recognition of the risen Lord in the breaking of bread.

verses.text: They were talking with each other about all these things that had happened.
verses.comment: The disciples are processing the events, showing active engagement with the mysteries of faith.

verses.text: While they were talking and discussing, Jesus Himself approached and began walking with them.
verses.comment: Jesus initiates encounter even when disciples do not recognize Him—a pattern seen in His dealings with humanity.

verses.text: But their eyes were kept from recognizing Him.
verses.comment: God sometimes withholds recognition to reveal a deeper understanding—often experienced in spiritual life until the fullness of revelation is given.

verses.text: He said to them, 'What are these words that you are exchanging with each other as you walk?' And they stood still, looking sad.
verses.comment: Jesus draws out their sorrow and misunderstanding, preparing them to receive the truth.

verses.text: One of them, named Cleopas, answered Him, 'Are you the only visitor in Jerusalem who does not know the things that have happened there in these days?'
verses.comment: Luke names one witness, further grounding the narrative in historical persons and events.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'What things?' They replied, 'The things about Jesus the Nazarene, who was a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people,
verses.comment: The disciples acknowledge Jesus’ authority as prophet; yet, the fullness of His identity surpasses their understanding.

verses.text: 'and how our chief priests and rulers delivered Him over to be sentenced to death, and crucified Him.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ suffering is seen as fulfilling Scripture and permitted by religious leaders; shows human responsibility and divine plan working together.

verses.text: But we had hoped that He was the one who was going to redeem Israel. Yes, and besides all this, it is now the third day since these things happened.
verses.comment: The hope for redemption is revealed. ‘Third day’ resonates with OT typology, as with Jonah and Hosea.

verses.text: Moreover, some women of our group amazed us. They went to the tomb early this morning,
verses.comment: Repeated testimony from multiple witnesses highlights the reliability and importance of the resurrection account.

verses.text: and when they did not find His body, they came, saying that they also had seen a vision of angels who said that He was alive.
verses.comment: Angelic testimony supports the foundational truth of Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: Some of those who were with us went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said, but Him they did not see.
verses.comment: Confirms the integrity and reliability of the witness testimony, fulfilled in an empty tomb—yet the Lord must reveal Himself.

verses.text: Then He said to them, 'O foolish and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have spoken!
verses.comment: Jesus rebukes them not for lack of information, but for unbelief in the Scriptures. True understanding comes with faith.

verses.text: Was it not necessary for the Messiah to suffer these things and to enter His glory?'
verses.comment: Jesus interprets His suffering as essential, fulfilling messianic prophecy—especially Isaiah 53.

verses.text: And beginning with Moses and all the prophets, He explained to them what was said in all the Scriptures concerning Himself.
verses.comment: Christ is the key to interpreting all Scripture. The OT finds its fulfillment in Him—a strong foundation for early Church theology.

verses.text: As they approached the village where they were going, He acted as though He were going farther.
verses.comment: Jesus invites a response from them, not forcing Himself upon them. Faith involves free cooperation with grace.

verses.text: But they urged Him strongly, saying, 'Stay with us, for it is nearly evening and the day is far spent.' So He went in to stay with them.
verses.comment: Hospitality, common in Jewish culture, allows for further revelation—a parallel to opening oneself to Christ more deeply.

verses.text: When He was at the table with them, He took bread, blessed and broke it, and gave it to them.
verses.comment: Many see in this language a direct allusion to the Lord’s Supper, linking recognition of Christ to the breaking of bread—a sacramental pattern for worship.

verses.text: Then their eyes were opened, and they recognized Him; and He vanished from their sight.
verses.comment: Recognition is granted in the context of the meal, pointing to the ongoing presence of Jesus with His people, especially through liturgical acts.

verses.text: They said to each other, 'Were not our hearts burning within us while He spoke to us on the road, while He opened the Scriptures to us?'
verses.comment: The Word and the breaking of bread together bring fullness of revelation. Spiritual understanding whets the appetite for deeper truth.

verses.text: So they got up that very hour and returned to Jerusalem. They found the Eleven and those with them gathered together,
verses.comment: Witness to Christ sends them back to the apostolic community—unity and communion as central marks of Christian life.

verses.text: saying, 'The Lord has truly been raised, and has appeared to Simon!'
verses.comment: Christ's appearance to Peter underlines his unique pastoral role, consistent with his primacy among the apostles.

verses.text: Then they described how He was made known to them in the breaking of bread.
verses.comment: Jesus’ presence is recognized in the Eucharistic act, highlighting the centrality of this meal in the continuing experience of the risen Lord.

verses.text: While they were still talking about this, Jesus Himself stood among them and said to them, 'Peace to you.'
verses.comment: The risen Jesus appears bodily, greeting the apostles with peace (Hebrew 'shalom'), signifying completion and reconciliation.

verses.text: But they were startled and frightened, and supposed that they saw a spirit.
verses.comment: Their fear reveals the reality of the resurrection as physical, not merely spiritual or visionary.

verses.text: And He said to them, 'Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your hearts?'
verses.comment: Jesus confronts their doubts, pointing to His bodily presence as the source of faith and assurance.

verses.text: 'Look at My hands and My feet, that it is I Myself. Touch Me and see; for a spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see that I have.'
verses.comment: The physicality of Jesus’ body affirms the reality of the resurrection—a cornerstone of apostolic faith. The marks of crucifixion remain visible.

verses.text: When He had said this, He showed them His hands and His feet.
verses.comment: The showing of the wounds is both proof and sign—the same Jesus who was crucified is risen.

verses.text: While they still could not believe it because of joy and were marveling, He said to them, 'Do you have anything here to eat?'
verses.comment: Eating is a further demonstration of His real, glorified body. Shared meals are a continuing theme of fellowship.

verses.text: They gave Him a piece of broiled fish.
verses.comment: The details underscore eyewitness testimony and emphasize the reality—not imagination—of the resurrection.

verses.text: He took it and ate before them.
verses.comment: Jesus' eating further proves He is not a ghost. Table fellowship continues to be a sign of the new life He brings.

verses.text: Then He said to them, 'These are My words that I spoke to you while I was still with you, that everything written about Me in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms must be fulfilled.'
verses.comment: The threefold division represents all of Scripture. Jesus fulfills all of God's promises—showing that the faith is rooted in continuity with Israel.

verses.text: Then He opened their minds to understand the Scriptures.
verses.comment: True understanding is a gift that comes through the action of Christ—the pattern for all subsequent understanding of God’s word.

verses.text: He said to them, 'Thus it is written, that the Messiah should suffer and rise from the dead on the third day,
verses.comment: Apostolic preaching is grounded in fulfillment of prophecy, uniting Old and New Covenants around Christ.

verses.text: and that repentance and forgiveness of sins should be proclaimed in His name to all nations, beginning from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The message is universal. Repentance and forgiveness together highlight the necessity of both faith and moral transformation, administered through the apostles.

verses.text: You are witnesses of these things.
verses.comment: Apostolic witness is the foundation of the faith, ensuring continuity and truth handed on through reliable testimony.

verses.text: And behold, I am sending the promise of My Father upon you. But stay in the city until you are clothed with power from on high.
verses.comment: The promise is fulfilled at Pentecost—the sending of the Spirit provides not merely private assurance, but authority and empowerment for ministry.

verses.text: Then He led them out as far as Bethany, and lifting up His hands, He blessed them.
verses.comment: The lifting of hands is a priestly gesture. Jesus, as eternal High Priest, blesses His apostles as He prepares to ascend.

verses.text: While He was blessing them, He parted from them and was carried up into heaven.
verses.comment: The ascension marks Christ’s enthronement at the right hand of God, completing His earthly mission, and beginning His heavenly intercession.

verses.text: And they, worshiping Him, returned to Jerusalem with great joy,
verses.comment: The disciples worship Jesus, recognizing His divinity—a breakthrough moment in the understanding of the early Church.

verses.text: and were continually in the temple blessing God.
verses.comment: Communal worship continues at the temple, signifying the reverent and apostolic nature of worship in the earliest era and its connection to the old covenant fulfilled in Christ.
